1023073629582450688.text:
In 18 months…

• Napster: 0 → 13M monthly active users
• Snapchat: 0 → 22M MAU

Napster launched in June 1999. Snapchat in Sept 2011.

Global internet usage ~4.5x'd 1999 → 2011. America, 1.5x

Basically what I'm saying is Napster's growth was even crazier than Snapchat's

One problem with the word "decentralized" is that it doesn't tell where data and coordination occurs. It just tells that it's not in one place. I prefer instead:

 "Local-first": SSB, Git
 "Federation": Mastodon
 "P2P Swarm": Bitcoin, DHTs

1121848693001469952.text: These results are very promising, and suggest that stateless clients for 1.x might be practical much sooner than expected (without a complicated major upgrade to the trie structure). Not to get too excited before we have data on recent blocks, but reason for optimism.

1121848691973922816.text: These are very reasonable block sizes for a 15 second block time. I (and perhaps many others) did not predict that reductions from deduplication and caching would be so significant. Was assumed that proof data would be too large, unless we change the trie structure (hard to do).

1121848690539364352.text: That's ~50kb blocks to delete all 6 gigs of contract storage! (estimates around block 5 million; still waiting on data for recent blocks). And ~75kb blocks to delete remaining 2 gigs of account state (8 gigs of state total, as a very rough estimate).

1121848688727527424.text:
Stateless clients for Eth1.x are looking better and better. Last update from @realLedgerwatch
showed within-block deduplication of proof data reduces block sizes by 3x (from 1mb to ~300kb). New update shows caching across 256 blocks reduces to ~50kb!https://twitter.com/realLedgerwatch/status/1121683089757917184?s=19 …

1120129020027461632.text: 5) A faster VM (whether EVM Evolution and/or Ewasm) at this point is moot because VM speed is not the bottleneck, disk I/O is. First priority for L1 scalability gains is to utilize more network I/O with stateless contracts. (And then squeeze out more gains with VM speed).

1120129018903375872.text: 4b) Exploring such a redesign with Ewasm: new direction "Ewasm 1.x". The old "Ewasm 1.0", based on legacy EVM storage model, is deprecated.

1120129017452081158.text: 4a) Related to (3), a storage rent mechanism with fees that are fair (or incentive-compatible) for multi-user contracts will require a radical redesign of the storage model (e.g. storage slots owned by user accounts, not by contracts).

1120129014927167494.text: 3b) Only way forward for dealing with legacy contract storage seems to be backwards-compatible stateless clients/contracts.

1120129011328475136.text: 3a) Imposing rent on existing contracts, without breaking them, is turning out to be much harder than first assumed. Every proposal thus far is untenable (e.g. will break DEX's) for one reason or another, even a simple SSTORE cost increase is problematic.

1120129008354713600.text: 2) Should be easy to reduce cost of CALLDATA / tx data. If reduced enough, will incentivize dapp devs to deploy stateless contracts going forward. (currently stateless contracts are not cost effective because calldata is way overpriced and sstore/sload way underpriced).

1120129007108939777.text: my summary: 1) Eth 1.x needs more "resources" / devs. Even straightforward todos such as chain data pruning don't have an active WG because existing client teams already too busy (let alone more ambitious todos like Vitalik's tx fee proposal).https://twitter.com/TaylorGerring/status/1120091031318487040?s=19 …

1087782971468333057.text:
Here's the code in geth for EIP100: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/391d4cb9b53eb9f71862cbb8a6cca332d5a76f94/consensus/ethash/consensus.go#L361 …

In Classic, uncles are never counted in the difficulty formula: https://github.com/ethereumclassic/go-ethereum/blob/296e6a9bf19a4fdfe9f76063f634f4463935a234/core/block_validator.go#L271 …

This implies an attacker could execute a double-spend with 10% of the hashpower (if not competing against another selfish miner).

1087781819133628416.text: Just realized that the selfish mining threshold on Ethereum Classic is 10% (or 5%, because of tie-breaking rule in geth), according to Niu and Feng. The threshold on Ethereum is 27% since Byzantium, thanks to EIP100. But EIP100 wasn't adopted on Classichttps://twitter.com/ittayeyal/status/1086884694136930305 …

1026937503780151301.text: Playing with a #RaspberryPi for the first time today, and having issues with Realtek wifi chip. Feels like I've been applying Realtek driver patches to the linux kernel for 20 years, wtf?
